Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet residency requirements under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Ambat comply with the residency obligation under s. 28 of the IRPA?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ambat spent only 312 days in Canada during the relevant period and worked in the UAE. His claim of employment by a Canadian business was rejected as the company lacked ongoing operations in Canada.
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Federal Court dismissed Ambat's application for judicial review.
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of IAD decision refusing travel document due to non-compliance
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Federal Court upheld the IAD's decision
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Remained outside Canada without meeting physical presence or employment-based exemption criteria
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Dispute over whether employment abroad qualified under s. 28 exception
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Permanent residents must be physically present in Canada for at least 730 days in a five-year period or employed full-time by a Canadian business outside Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Actual days in Canada; validity of foreign employment arrangement
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation of errors in legal interpretation and procedural fairness before IAD
Crimes.Review_Standard: Standard of reasonableness in reviewing administrative decisions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: IAD determined the Canadian business had no real operations and was used to circumvent rules
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Employment contracts, corporate registration, financial records, travel history
Crimes.Application_Basis: Residency through physical presence or authorized absence via qualifying employment
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Operational substance of the Canadian employer and nature of work performed abroad
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturning of IAD decision and recognition of compliance with residency obligation
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Under s. 28 of the IRPA, permanent residents must be physically present in Canada for at least 730 days in a five-year period or employed full-time by a Canadian business outside Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of active Canadian business supporting foreign employment claim
Crimes.Outcome: IAD's decision upheld; residency obligation unfulfilled
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Refusal of travel document and potential loss of permanent resident status
Crimes.Cause_Description: Ambat's application for a travel document was refused due to non-compliance with residency obligations
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: IAD reviewed and rejected documentary support for employment claim
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Authenticity and sufficiency of documents proving qualifying employment
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed – only 312 days in Canada, no valid employment exception
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Creation of shell Canadian business to falsely support residency exception
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over immigration residency determinations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: IAD found insufficient proof of genuine employment relationship
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Ambat did not satisfy either prong of s. 28; decision was reasonable
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of corroborating evidence for foreign employment claim
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of IAD’s factual findings and legal interpretation
